questions.text: Please upload photos of the damage. (This is the most important input for repair quoting — show us close-ups and wide shots)
questions.hint: Take photos from multiple angles: 1) Overall view of the full piece, 2) Close-up of the damaged area, 3) Any visible rust or deterioration. Good photos can save you a site visit fee.
Select all that apply. Multiple issues are common with older ornamental iron.

questions.text: Does the replacement piece need to match the existing design exactly?
options: Yes — must match exactly (may require custom forming/forging)
questions.hint: Exact matching of old ornamental work can be significantly more labor-intensive than a close approximation.

questions.text: What type of item is this?
questions.hint: This helps us scope the repair and understand the structural requirements.

questions.text: Can you see any rust? (This helps identify the material)
options: Yes — orange/brown rust (mild steel or wrought iron)
No rust but looks dark/aged (could be aluminum or coated steel)
No rust, shiny silver (stainless or aluminum)
Heavy flaking rust (likely old wrought iron)
questions.hint: Orange rust = ferrous metal (steel or iron). No rust ever = likely aluminum or stainless. Galvanized steel gets white/gray corrosion.

questions.text: Approximate dimensions of the damaged area?
questions.hint: Length x width of the area that needs work. Even a rough estimate helps — e.g., '2 feet of railing' or 'a 6-inch section of the post'.

options: Structural — load-bearing or safety-critical (railing you lean on, gate that holds weight)
Cosmetic — visual only (decorative scroll, finial, non-structural piece)
Both — structural integrity is compromised AND it looks bad
questions.hint: Structural repairs must meet code. Cosmetic repairs focus on appearance match. If in doubt, we'll treat it as structural.

questions.text: Will matching the existing finish be required?
options: Yes — need to match existing paint/patina
No — just repair, don't worry about finish
questions.hint: Matching old patina or paint is harder and more expensive than refinishing the whole piece. If the existing finish is failing anyway, refinishing everything often makes more sense.

questions.text: Approximate age of the existing ironwork?
questions.hint: Older ironwork may have hidden deterioration, different alloys, or lead paint. This affects repair approach and cost.

questions.text: Can the piece be removed and brought to the shop, or is it on-site only?
options: Can be removed — bring to shop
Must stay in place — on-site repair only
questions.hint: Shop repair is usually better quality and cheaper. On-site repair is necessary for large/fixed pieces but costs more (on-site rate applies).

questions.text: Any access constraints at the site?
questions.hint: Welding at height or in confined spaces adds significant time and may require additional safety equipment.

questions.text: Would you like a site visit to assess before quoting? (1-1.5 hours at shop rate)
options: Maybe — let me see the photo-based estimate first
questions.hint: Complex repairs often benefit from an in-person look. The site visit fee is typically credited toward the job if you proceed.

questions.text: Is there damage beyond the primary repair area?
options: Yes — widespread deterioration (may need full replacement discussion)
questions.hint: This is a common scope creep flag. Better to know upfront than discover it mid-repair.

questions.text: What finish for the repaired area?
options: Match existing (blend repair into existing finish)
Refinish entire piece (strip and recoat everything)
questions.hint: Spot-matching is tricky and may show. Refinishing the whole piece gives the best result.

questions.text: Do you have a budget range in mind?
options: No budget in mind — just need it fixed
Want to compare repair vs. replacement cost
questions.hint: This helps us calibrate between a quick functional fix and a full restoration. Sometimes replacement is more cost-effective than repair.
